Preconditioned Federated Learning


 


Zeyi Tao                        Jindi Wu                        Qun Li

Department of Computer Science William & Mary Williamsburg, VA, USA ztao, jwu21, liqun@wm.edu

Abstract

Federated Learning (FL) is a distributed machine learning approach that enables model training in communication efficient and privacy-preserving manner. The standard optimization method in FL is Federated Averaging (FedAvg), which performs multiple local SGD steps between communication rounds. FedAvg has been considered to lack algorithm adaptivity compared to modern first-order adaptive optimizations. In this paper, we propose new communication-efficient FL algortithms based on two adaptive frameworks: local adaptivity (PreFed) and server-side adaptivity (PreFedOp). Proposed methods adopt adaptivity by using a novel covariance matrix preconditioner. Theoretically, we provide convergence guarantees for our algorithms. The empirical experiments show our methods achieve state-of-the-art performances on both i.i.d. and non-i.i.d. settings.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) [McMahan et al., 2017] is a distributed learning paradigm that collaboratively trains models in heterogeneous networks without data sharing. FL performs the model update in parallel on a small subset of the total clients and averages the local models on a centralized server only once in a while.

FL has two fundamental characters that distinguish it from the standard parallel optimization. First, the training data is non-iid [Li et al., 2019, Li et al., 2020]. In FL, the data is massively distributed over different clients such as banks, hospitals, and information institutions [Kairouz et al., 2019]. Data shard on each client is sampled from a possibly different distribution (a.k.a., heterogeneous or non-i.i.d. data samples). Consequently, local data fail to represent the overall distribution. Data heterogeneity does not only bring challenges to algorithm design but also makes theoretical analysis much harder. Second, considerable clients are involved in FL training ranging from smartphones, network sensors to powerful servers. The standard distributed optimizations, such as stochastic gradient descent (SGD), may not be suitable for FL due to the high communication cost of iterative gradient methods.

In order to handle heterogeneity and tackle high communication costs, communication-efficient optimization methods are widely adopted. Federated averaging (FedAvg) [McMahan et al., 2017] is the first and perhaps the most widely used FL algorithm. FedAvg runs K𝐾K steps of SGD in parallel on a small sampled subset of devices before performing global model synchronization. In this way, FedAvg can significantly reduce the amount of communication required to train a model.

While FedAvg has demonstrated empirical success in certain applications, recent works have highlighted its slow convergence issues in heterogeneous settings. This is due to (1) model divergence [Li et al., 2018, Karimireddy et al., 2019], where locally trained models drift away from globally optimal models causing slow and unstable convergence, and (2) a lack of adaptivity [Reddi et al., 2020]. FedAvg updates local models via vanilla SGD, resulting in poor performance if we train models with heavy-tail stochastic gradient noise distributions such as language models.  [Zhang et al., 2019] theoretically have showed that the preconditioned methods such as AdaGrad [Duchi et al., 2011], Adam [Kingma and Ba, 2014], and AMSGrad [Reddi et al., 2019] have better performance in such settings. Spurred by the advances of preconditioned methods, [Reddi et al., 2020] proposed the first decentralized Adam method (FedAdam) directly applied to federated learning.

In this work, we propose preconditioned federated algorithms based on two different adaptive frameworks: client-side [Xie et al., 2019] and server-side [Reddi et al., 2020]. We first propose Preconditioned Federated (PreFed) algorithm, a client-side adaptive federated optimization that accelerates the client models training. In addition, we propose PreFedOpt algorithm, where the adaptivity is applied only on the server. For both proposed algorithms, we achieve adaptivity by using a covariance matrix-based preconditioner [Ida et al., 2016]. We periodically synchronize this preconditioner over all clients on a centralized server.

A key insight we have in developing proposed algorithms is that covariance matrix preconditioner reduces the noise in the stochastic gradient-based approximation of Fisher information [Amari, 1998]. Therefore the curvature in the loss landscape can be precisely captured by noise-reduced Fisher information to accelerate the gradient descent training [Dauphin et al., 2015, Ida et al., 2016, Balles and Hennig, 2018].

In light of the above, we highlight the main contributions of the paper. We propose preconditioned FL algorithms (PreFed and PreFedOpt) based on two adaptive federated optimization frameworks. We provide convergence guarantees for our methods for non-convex online FL optimizations. Despite encouraging theoretical results, our empirical evaluation indicates that our methods consistently outperform recent state-of-the-art adaptive federated algorithms.

2 Related Work

There is an enormous amount of work studying standard federated optimization111By saying standard federated optimization, we refer to the non-adaptive federated optimization such as FedAvg [McMahan et al., 2017], SCAFFOLD [Karimireddy et al., 2019], etc. [Li et al., 2018, Li et al., 2019, Haddadpour and Mahdavi, 2019] and first-order preconditioning [Dauphin et al., 2015, Qu et al., 2020, Bischoff et al., 2021, Li, 2018], which is too much to discuss here in detail. Thus, we only briefly discuss two lines of work that are most relevant to our paper here. First, adaptive federated optimzation e.g., [Xie et al., 2019, Reddi et al., 2020], to understand and give theoretical guarantees. Second, the covariance matrix-based gradient descent preconditioning [Ida et al., 2016].

Adaptive Federated Learning In order to solve the federated learning problem [McMahan et al., 2017] first proposed FedAvg as a communication efficient FL algorithm. FedAvg runs vanilla SGD on client model updates and averages the client models to produce the new global model for next round training.

To accommodate the first-order adaptive methods,  [Xie et al., 2019] proposed AdaAlter, a method for FL that allows the client models to use adaptive learning rates. AdaAlter uses the same adaptive term as AdaGrad222Adagrad uses the square root of the sum of the outer product of the past gradients to achieve adaptivity such as ∑i=1tgi​gi⊤superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡subscript𝑔𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖top\sum_{i=1}^{t}g_{i}g_{i}^{\top} at t𝑡t-th round or its variants and simultaneously performs lazy adaptive term updates on global model synchronization. AdaAlter has been proven that achieves 𝒪​(1/T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T}) convergence rate on federated optimization. However, the empirical result on the 1 billion words dataset shows that AdaAlter highly depends on the adaptive term synchronization, which makes communication inefficient.

Recently, [Reddi et al., 2020] developed the first generic framework for federated optimization using adaptive first-order gradient descent algorithms named FedOpt. FedOpt has two optimizers ClientOpt and ServerOpt. ClientOpt, similar to FedAvg, performs parallel SGD on the client model. While the SeverOpt adopts adaptive optimization (one of AdaGrad, YOGI, or Adam) for parameter updates on the server. Further, is has been shown that the AdaAlter is a special case of FedOpt. FedOpt, compared to the AdaAlter, avoids aggregating optimizer states across clients, making it more communication efficient. We illustrate FedAdaGrad in Algorithm 1 as a reference.

Covariance matrix-based SGD preconditioning Recently, many works have focused on preconditioned SGD methods [Dauphin et al., 2015, Ida et al., 2016, Staib et al., 2019, Qu et al., 2020]. The preconditioners can be categorized into the Newton type and the Fisher type [Amari, 1998]. The Newton type is closely related to the Newton method, and is suitable for small and middle scale machine learning problems due to computational efficiency reasons. The Fisher type preconditioner that uses the inverse of Fisher information matrix is more appealing because the Fisher information metric can be well defined in most learning problems.

The empirical success of adaptive methods such as Adam could be explained by using preconditioned SGD. In particular, the adaptivity of Adam is an approximation to the Fisher information matrix by accumulating first-order gradients in the past. To acquire a better approximation of Fisher information,  [Ida et al., 2016] proposed covariance matrix-based SGD preconditioning (SDProp) by reducing the noise of gradient covariance. Empirical results of SDProp have shown that effectively handling the noise present in the gradients can improve the network’s performance on image classification and language tasks. Nerveless, SDProp lacks theoretical analysis on convergence.

In this work, we apply the covariance matrix-based preconditioner to FL to accelerate the training and improve the overall model performance. To our best knowledge, there is no preconditioning method has been applied in FL optimization so far. Our method is perhaps the first one.

3 Preliminaries

3.1 Notations and Problem Formulation

3.2 Adaptive Federated Optimization

Client-side Adaptivity Adding adaptivity to the above settings of FL is straightforward. In [Xie et al., 2019] work (AdaAlter), instead of using vanilla SGD on the local client like Equation 3, AdaAlter performs adaptive local updates:

(on Client i)wi,kt=wi,k−1t−ηvi,kt+τ⊙gi,kt(on Client i)superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘1𝑡direct-product𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖𝑘𝑡𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑘𝑡\text{(on Client i)}\quad w_{i,k}^{t}=w_{i,k-1}^{t}-\frac{\eta}{\sqrt{v_{i,k}^{t}}+\tau}\odot g_{i,k}^{t} (4)

where τ𝜏\tau controls the algorithms’ degree of adaptivity [Reddi et al., 2020]. vi,ktsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖𝑘𝑡v_{i,k}^{t} is AdaGrad-liked preconditioner defined as vi,kt=vi,k−1t+gi,kt⊙gi,ktsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖𝑘1𝑡direct-productsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑘𝑡v_{i,k}^{t}=v_{i,k-1}^{t}+g_{i,k}^{t}\odot g_{i,k}^{t}. AdaAlter synchronizes model parameters periodically as standard FedAvg does. In addition, AdaAlter updates preconditioner such that vt+1=1s​∑i∈𝒮vi,Ktsubscript𝑣𝑡11𝑠subscript𝑖𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖𝐾𝑡v_{t+1}=\frac{1}{s}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}v_{i,K}^{t} over all participating clients.

Server-side Adaptivity [Reddi et al., 2020] proposed FedOpt (or FedAdaGrad) that applies the adaptivity when the central server performs global model fusion e.g.,

(on Server)wt+1=wt−ηvt+τ⊙Δt(on Server)subscript𝑤𝑡1subscript𝑤𝑡direct-product𝜂subscript𝑣𝑡𝜏subscriptΔ𝑡\text{(on Server)}\quad w_{t+1}=w_{t}-\frac{\eta}{\sqrt{v_{t}}+\tau}\odot\Delta_{t} (5)

where Δt=∑i=1mwi,Kt−wtsubscriptΔ𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑡𝑖𝐾subscript𝑤𝑡\Delta_{t}=\sum_{i=1}^{m}w^{t}_{i,K}-w_{t} and vt=vt−1+Δt⊙Δtsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝑣𝑡1direct-productsubscriptΔ𝑡subscriptΔ𝑡v_{t}=v_{t-1}+\Delta_{t}\odot\Delta_{t}. Algorithm 1 provides more details about FedAdaGrad. Clearly, FedAdaGrad does not require extra communication, and one can directly apply FedAdaGrad to the current FL without any further modification.

3.3 Preconditioned SGD

Adaptive learning rate algorithms are widely used for the efficient training of deep neural networks. The empirical success of adaptive methods could be explained by using preconditioned SGD [Dauphin et al., 2015]. In precondition, we seek to locally transform the curvature of the loss function so that its curvature is equal in all directions. A direct benefit of this is gradient descent method could escape from the saddle point much easier, which has been recently found as a major obstacle in machine learning training [Choromanska et al., 2015].

Preconditioned SGD works in this way. Consider a loss function f𝑓f with parameter w∈Rd𝑤superscript𝑅𝑑w\in R^{d}. We introduce a linear transform of variables w^=P12​w^𝑤superscript𝑃12𝑤\hat{w}=P^{\frac{1}{2}}w with a non-singular matrix P12superscript𝑃12P^{\frac{1}{2}}. Now, instead of performing optimization on f​(w)𝑓𝑤f(w), we focus on variable transformed function f^​(w^)^𝑓^𝑤\hat{f}(\hat{w}). The gradient and hessian of f^​(w^)^𝑓^𝑤\hat{f}(\hat{w}) with respect to w𝑤w are P−12​∇f​(w)superscript𝑃12∇𝑓𝑤P^{-\frac{1}{2}}\nabla f(w) and P−12​H​P−12superscript𝑃12𝐻superscript𝑃12P^{-\frac{1}{2}}HP^{-\frac{1}{2}}. Here H=∇2f​(w)𝐻superscript∇2𝑓𝑤H=\nabla^{2}f(w) is Hessian matrix. Consequently, the gradient descent for optimizing f^​(w^)^𝑓^𝑤\hat{f}(\hat{w}) transform to:

wt=wt−1−ηt​Pt−1​∇f​(w)subscript𝑤𝑡subscript𝑤𝑡1subscript𝜂𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑡1∇𝑓𝑤w_{t}=w_{t-1}-\eta_{t}P_{t}^{-1}\nabla f(w) (6)

with respect to the original variable w𝑤w. Particularly, when P12=H12superscript𝑃12superscript𝐻12P^{\frac{1}{2}}=H^{\frac{1}{2}}, the new Hessian ∇2f^​(w^)=Isuperscript∇2^𝑓^𝑤𝐼\nabla^{2}\hat{f}(\hat{w})=I is perfectly conditioned and Equation 6 corresponds the Newton method. Searching for perfect conditioner P12=H12superscript𝑃12superscript𝐻12P^{\frac{1}{2}}=H^{\frac{1}{2}} is prohibited in modern neural networks because H12superscript𝐻12H^{\frac{1}{2}} exists only when H𝐻H is positive-semidefinite and has high computational complexity (e.g.𝒪​(d3)𝒪superscript𝑑3\mathcal{O}(d^{3})).

To avoid using Hessian to obtain the curvature information, adaptive methods like AdaGrad and RMSProp use the Fisher-type preconditioner Pt=∑i=1tgi​gi⊤subscript𝑃𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡subscript𝑔𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖topP_{t}=\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{t}g_{i}g_{i}^{\top}} and Pt=(1−β)​∑i=1tβt−i​gi​gi⊤subscript𝑃𝑡1𝛽superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡superscript𝛽𝑡𝑖subscript𝑔𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖topP_{t}=\sqrt{(1-\beta)\sum_{i=1}^{t}\beta^{t-i}g_{i}g_{i}^{\top}} respectively.333In RMSProp β>0𝛽0\beta>0 is chosen appropriately such that (1−β)​∑i=1tβt−i​gi​gi⊤≈𝔼​[gt​gt⊤]1𝛽superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡superscript𝛽𝑡𝑖subscript𝑔𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖top𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑔𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑡top\sqrt{(1-\beta)\sum_{i=1}^{t}\beta^{t-i}g_{i}g_{i}^{\top}}\approx\mathbb{E}[g_{t}g_{t}^{\top}] The Fisher information can also capture curvature information in the loss landscape if the objective function is a log-likelihood [Staib et al., 2019]. In most cases, this condition holds where we often use cross-entropy as our loss function. Hence, 𝔼​[g​g⊤]𝔼delimited-[]𝑔superscript𝑔top\mathbb{E}[gg^{\top}] approximates the Fisher information matrix, which present curvature information in the parameter space.

However, in stochastic optimization approaches such as mini-batch settings, the first-order gradients always contain noise. Consequently, the square root of the uncentered variances in Ptsubscript𝑃𝑡P_{t} contains noise, producing an approximation of the Fisher information matrix with noise.

4 Proposed Method

In this section, we discuss the motivation behind our proposed methods. The key insight of our proposed method is that we construct more precise Fisher information by using a noise-reduced covariance matrix. Then we present two new adaptive federated algorithms based on two adaptive FL optimization frameworks.

4.1 Motivation

In general, consider an objective function F​(w)𝐹𝑤F(w) with parameter w𝑤w. The preconditioned SGD has the following updated rule:

wt=wt−1−η​Pt−1​gt=wt−1−η​Pt−1​∇F​(wt)−η​Pt−1​(gt−∇F​(wt))subscript𝑤𝑡subscript𝑤𝑡1𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑡1subscript𝑔𝑡subscript𝑤𝑡1𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑡1∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑡𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑡1subscript𝑔𝑡∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑡\begin{split}w_{t}&=w_{t-1}-\eta P_{t}^{-1}g_{t}\\ &=w_{t-1}-\eta P_{t}^{-1}\nabla F(w_{t})-\eta P_{t}^{-1}(g_{t}-\nabla F(w_{t}))\end{split} (7)

where ∇F​(w)∇𝐹𝑤\nabla F(w) is true gradient at w𝑤w and gt=∇F​(wt,d)subscript𝑔𝑡∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑡𝑑g_{t}=\nabla F(w_{t},d) is noised gradient. The Pt−1​∇F​(wt)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑡1∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑡P_{t}^{-1}\nabla F(w_{t}) term is deterministic. The Pt−1​(gt−∇F​(wt))superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑡1subscript𝑔𝑡∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑡P_{t}^{-1}(g_{t}-\nabla F(w_{t})) is measuring the stochastic gradient noise. By letting stochastic gradient gtsubscript𝑔𝑡g_{t} with mean of 𝔼​[gt]=∇F​(w)𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑔𝑡∇𝐹𝑤\mathbb{E}[g_{t}]=\nabla F(w) and assume Pt=𝔼​[gt​gt⊤]1/2subscript𝑃𝑡𝔼superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑔𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑡top12P_{t}=\mathbb{E}[g_{t}g_{t}^{\top}]^{1/2} where 𝔼​[gt​gt⊤]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑔𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑡top\mathbb{E}[g_{t}g_{t}^{\top}] is non-singular. Based on the recent study [Staib et al., 2019], the stochastic noise ζt=Pt−1​(gt−∇F​(wt))subscript𝜁𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑡1subscript𝑔𝑡∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑡\zeta_{t}=P_{t}^{-1}(g_{t}-\nabla F(w_{t})) has mean 𝔼​[ζt]=0𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝜁𝑡0\mathbb{E}[\zeta_{t}]=0 and covariance:

Cov​(ζt)=I−Pt−1​∇F​(wt)​∇F​(wt)⊤​(Pt−1)⊤Covsubscript𝜁𝑡𝐼superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑡1∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑡∇𝐹superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑡topsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑡1top\text{Cov}(\zeta_{t})=I-P_{t}^{-1}\nabla F(w_{t})\nabla F(w_{t})^{\top}(P_{t}^{-1})^{\top} (8)

Given the adaptive setting above, the covariance Cov​(ζt)Covsubscript𝜁𝑡\text{Cov}(\zeta_{t}) is approximately the identity matrix I𝐼I for all t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T].

This observation demonstrates one of the reasons for the success of precondition (adaptive) methods on non-convex optimization. It is well-known that gradient descent methods make slow progress when the curvature of the loss function is very different in separate directions [Dauphin et al., 2015]. When Equation 8 is an identical matrix, it ensures the gradient noise is approximately isotropic. The curvature of the optimization surface is equal in all directions making the optimizer quickly escapes from the saddle point.

Intuitively, the noise of stochastic gradient is even higher due to heterogeneous settings. Such high gradient variance may cause non-isotropic curvature slowing down the training. Can we reduce gradient variance across all client gradients via precondition? This is the primary motivation behind our approach. In addition, our approach should be computation and communication efficient. In the next section, we present our preconditioned FL optimization algorithms.

4.2 Preconditioned Federated Optimization

First, it is natural to assume the first-order gradients follow Gaussian distributions in FL due to the recent observations on probabilistic modeling [Sra et al., 2012, Andrychowicz et al., 2016, Zhang et al., 2018]. By following [Ida et al., 2016], we assume the gradient on i𝑖i-th client gi,t=∇Fi​(wt,di)∈Rdsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑡∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝑤𝑡subscript𝑑𝑖superscript𝑅𝑑g_{i,t}=\nabla F_{i}(w_{t},d_{i})\in R^{d}:

gi,t∼𝒩​(g¯t,Ci,t)∀i∈[m]formulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscript𝑔𝑖𝑡𝒩subscript¯𝑔𝑡subscript𝐶𝑖𝑡for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑚g_{i,t}\sim\mathcal{N}(\bar{g}_{t},C_{i,t})\quad\forall i\in[m] (9)

where g¯t=∇F​(wt)subscript¯𝑔𝑡∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑡\bar{g}_{t}=\nabla F(w_{t}) is the true gradient without the noise. 𝒩​(g¯t,Ci,t)𝒩subscript¯𝑔𝑡subscript𝐶𝑖𝑡\mathcal{N}(\bar{g}_{t},C_{i,t}) is a Gaussian distribution with mean g¯tsubscript¯𝑔𝑡\bar{g}_{t} and covariance matrix Ci,tsubscript𝐶𝑖𝑡C_{i,t} and Ci,tsubscript𝐶𝑖𝑡C_{i,t} is the covariance matrix of gi,tsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑡g_{i,t} whose size is d×d𝑑𝑑d\times d. Suppose we use m𝑚m clients to perform synchronization. Then we have m𝑚m normally distributed gradients such as g1,t,⋯,gm,tsubscript𝑔1𝑡⋯subscript𝑔𝑚𝑡g_{1,t},\cdots,g_{m,t}. The distribution of averaged gradient over m𝑚m clients of Gt=1s​∑i∈𝒮gi,tsubscript𝐺𝑡1𝑠subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝑔𝑖𝑡G_{t}=\frac{1}{s}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}g_{i,t} is given

Gt∼𝒩​(g¯t,1m2​Σt)similar-tosubscript𝐺𝑡𝒩subscript¯𝑔𝑡1superscript𝑚2subscriptΣ𝑡G_{t}\sim\mathcal{N}(\bar{g}_{t},\frac{1}{m^{2}}\Sigma_{t}) (10)

where Σt=C1,t+⋯+Cm,tsubscriptΣ𝑡subscript𝐶1𝑡⋯subscript𝐶𝑚𝑡\Sigma_{t}=C_{1,t}+\cdots+C_{m,t} is sum of m𝑚m covariance matrices. ΣtsubscriptΣ𝑡\Sigma_{t} has the same size of covariance matrices as d×d𝑑𝑑d\times d. Since Cm,tsubscript𝐶𝑚𝑡C_{m,t} is assumed to be a positive semi-definite matrix, ΣtsubscriptΣ𝑡\Sigma_{t} is also positive semi-definite matrix. Later we can decompose ΣtsubscriptΣ𝑡\Sigma_{t} as Σt=V​D​V⊤subscriptΣ𝑡𝑉𝐷superscript𝑉top\Sigma_{t}=VDV^{\top} where V𝑉V is an orthogonal matrix of d×d𝑑𝑑d\times d and D𝐷D is a diagonal matrix of eigenvalues.

We define preconditioned gradient G^t=Pt−1​Gtsubscript^𝐺𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑡1subscript𝐺𝑡\hat{G}_{t}=P_{t}^{-1}G_{t}. The distribution of transformed gradient changes to

G^t∼𝒩​(Pt−1​g¯t,1m2​Pt−1​Σt​(Pt−1)⊤)similar-tosubscript^𝐺𝑡𝒩superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑡1subscript¯𝑔𝑡1superscript𝑚2superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑡1subscriptΣ𝑡superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑡1top\hat{G}_{t}\sim\mathcal{N}(P_{t}^{-1}\bar{g}_{t},\frac{1}{m^{2}}P_{t}^{-1}\Sigma_{t}(P_{t}^{-1})^{\top}) (11)

Equation 11 is hold due to the linear transform of random variable from normal distribution. If random variable X∼𝒩​(μ,Σ)similar-to𝑋𝒩𝜇ΣX\sim\mathcal{N}(\mu,\Sigma) and Y=A​X+B𝑌𝐴𝑋𝐵Y=AX+B, then Y∼𝒩​(A​μ,A​Σ​A⊤+ΣB)similar-to𝑌𝒩𝐴𝜇𝐴Σsuperscript𝐴topsubscriptΣ𝐵Y\sim\mathcal{N}(A\mu,A\Sigma A^{\top}+\Sigma_{B}). Now, we can reduce the covariance of G^tsubscript^𝐺𝑡\hat{G}_{t} to 1m2​I1superscript𝑚2𝐼\frac{1}{m^{2}}I by letting Pt=Σt12subscript𝑃𝑡superscriptsubscriptΣ𝑡12P_{t}=\Sigma_{t}^{\frac{1}{2}} such that

G^t∼𝒩​(Pt−1​g¯t,1m2​Pt−1​Σt​(Pt−1)⊤)∼𝒩​(Σ−12​g¯t,1m2​Σ−12​Σt​(Σ−12)⊤)∼𝒩​(Σ−12​g¯t,1m2​V​D−12​V−1​V​D​V−1​(V​D​V−1)⊤)∼𝒩​(Σ−12​g¯t,1m2​I)similar-tosubscript^𝐺𝑡𝒩superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑡1subscript¯𝑔𝑡1superscript𝑚2superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑡1subscriptΣ𝑡superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑡1topsimilar-to𝒩superscriptΣ12subscript¯𝑔𝑡1superscript𝑚2superscriptΣ12subscriptΣ𝑡superscriptsuperscriptΣ12topsimilar-to𝒩superscriptΣ12subscript¯𝑔𝑡1superscript𝑚2𝑉superscript𝐷12superscript𝑉1𝑉𝐷superscript𝑉1superscript𝑉𝐷superscript𝑉1topsimilar-to𝒩superscriptΣ12subscript¯𝑔𝑡1superscript𝑚2𝐼\begin{split}\hat{G}_{t}&\sim\mathcal{N}(P_{t}^{-1}\bar{g}_{t},\frac{1}{m^{2}}P_{t}^{-1}\Sigma_{t}(P_{t}^{-1})^{\top})\\ &\sim\mathcal{N}(\Sigma^{-\frac{1}{2}}\bar{g}_{t},\frac{1}{m^{2}}\Sigma^{-\frac{1}{2}}\Sigma_{t}(\Sigma^{-\frac{1}{2}})^{\top})\\ &\sim\mathcal{N}(\Sigma^{-\frac{1}{2}}\bar{g}_{t},\frac{1}{m^{2}}VD^{-\frac{1}{2}}V^{-1}VDV^{-1}(VDV^{-1})^{\top})\\ &\sim\mathcal{N}(\Sigma^{-\frac{1}{2}}\bar{g}_{t},\frac{1}{m^{2}}I)\end{split} (12)

Third line is due to orthogonal matrix V𝑉V with V​V⊤=I𝑉superscript𝑉top𝐼VV^{\top}=I and (V​D​V−1)⊤=V​D​V−1superscript𝑉𝐷superscript𝑉1top𝑉𝐷superscript𝑉1(VDV^{-1})^{\top}=VDV^{-1}. Equation 12 indicates that the transformation of G^t=Σt−12​Gtsubscript^𝐺𝑡superscriptsubscriptΣ𝑡12subscript𝐺𝑡\hat{G}_{t}=\Sigma_{t}^{-\frac{1}{2}}G_{t} result in the Gaussian distribution of G^tsubscript^𝐺𝑡\hat{G}_{t} whose covariance matrix is scaled identity matrix 1m2​I1superscript𝑚2𝐼\frac{1}{m^{2}}I. When we increase the number of participated clients, the gradient variance decreases as 𝒪​(1/m2)𝒪1superscript𝑚2\mathcal{O}(1/m^{2}).

In this way, we reduce the preconditioned gradient noises and ensure they are equal in all directions. We introduce the basic version online updating rule of preconditioned federated optimization, and we leave more discussion in the next section. We compute the first order gradients parallelly at each local iteration on each client as gi,k=∇Fi​(wi,kt)subscript𝑔𝑖𝑘∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘𝑡g_{i,k}=\nabla F_{i}(w_{i,k}^{t}). We compute averaged gradient

mkt=1|𝒮|​∑i∈𝒮gi,ksuperscriptsubscript𝑚𝑘𝑡1𝒮subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝑔𝑖𝑘m_{k}^{t}=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{S}|}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}g_{i,k} (13)

over all selected clients. The local covariance based preconditioner is computed according to

Pi,k=Pi,k−1+(gi,k−mkt)⊙(gi,k−mkt)subscript𝑃𝑖𝑘subscript𝑃𝑖𝑘1direct-productsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑘𝑡subscript𝑔𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑘𝑡P_{i,k}=P_{i,k-1}+(g_{i,k}-m_{k}^{t})\odot(g_{i,k}-m_{k}^{t}) (14)

We update the local model on i𝑖i-th client at k𝑘k-th step:

wi,k+1t=wi,kt−ηtPi,k+τ⊙gi,ksuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘𝑡direct-productsubscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝑃𝑖𝑘𝜏subscript𝑔𝑖𝑘w_{i,k+1}^{t}=w_{i,k}^{t}-\frac{\eta_{t}}{\sqrt{P_{i,k}}+\tau}\odot g_{i,k} (15)

Clearly, the update rule in Equation 15 is not communication efficient due to the synchronization in every local iteration. We address the communication issue by using (1) lazy update of preconditioner and (2) server-side preconditioning. The next section formally presents our efficient preconditioned federated optimization algorithm under the above two settings.

4.3 PreFed and PreFedOpt

To reduce the communication cost on preconditioned FL optimization (Equation 15), we adopt (1) a lazy preconditioner update PreFed (Algorithm 2). We simultaneously update covariance preconditioner Ptsubscript𝑃𝑡P_{t} on global model synchronization; (2) the server-side preconditioning PreFedOpt (Algorithm 3). That is, instead of performing local preconditioning on each client model, we only apply preconditioner on global model update.

PreFed has the same design pattern as AdaAlter, in which we perform preconditioning (adaptivity) on each client and synchronize the preconditioner (adaptive term) on a server over time. Since the accumulator mtsubscript𝑚𝑡m_{t} and Ptsubscript𝑃𝑡P_{t} are the same sizes as the model’s trainable weights, client-to-server communication doubles for PreFed, relative to FedAvg. On the other hand, the local precondition accelerates the convergence speed of the client model. The trade-off between convergence rate and communication cost is studied in section X. One simple way to reduce the communication cost is using the diagonal preconditioner. For example, we do not share the full matrices. Instead, we use diagonal covariance matrices:

Pt=Pt−1+diag​((gt−mt)⊙(gt−mt))subscript𝑃𝑡subscript𝑃𝑡1diagdirect-productsubscript𝑔𝑡subscript𝑚𝑡subscript𝑔𝑡subscript𝑚𝑡P_{t}=P_{t-1}+\text{diag}((g_{t}-m_{t})\odot(g_{t}-m_{t})) (16)

We omit the client id i𝑖i and local iteration k𝑘k for simply demonstrating the percondistioner update rule (also applies on the following Equation 17 and 18). Since this approach only needs the diagonal terms, the memory and computation costs are 𝒪​(d)𝒪𝑑\mathcal{O}(d).

By contrast, PreFedOp does not require extra communication or client memory relative to PreFed. Thus, we see that server-side adaptive optimization benefits from lower per-round communication and client memory requirements, which is essential for FL applications. In PreFed and PreFedOpt, gradient coordinates are scaled with the accumulated information of all the past squared gradients like AdaGrad. A significant drawback of using the AdaGrad liked preconditioner in Equation 14 is the progressive increase of its elements, which leads to a rapid decrease of the learning rate. To prevent this monotonically decreasing learning rate, we modify the PreFed’s (also PreFedOpt) preconditioner by using exponential moving average (EMA). By adequately choosing decay parameter β>0𝛽0\beta>0, we change preconditioner update rule 14 to:

Pt=β​Pt+(1−β)​(gt−mt)⊙(gt−mt)subscript𝑃𝑡𝛽subscript𝑃𝑡direct-product1𝛽subscript𝑔𝑡subscript𝑚𝑡subscript𝑔𝑡subscript𝑚𝑡P_{t}=\beta P_{t}+(1-\beta)(g_{t}-m_{t})\odot(g_{t}-m_{t}) (17)

For PreFedOpt, similarly, we perform server-side preconditioner update:

Pt=β​Pt−1+(1−β)​(Δt−mt)⊙(Δt−mt)subscript𝑃𝑡𝛽subscript𝑃𝑡1direct-product1𝛽subscriptΔ𝑡subscript𝑚𝑡subscriptΔ𝑡subscript𝑚𝑡P_{t}=\beta P_{t-1}+(1-\beta)(\Delta_{t}-m_{t})\odot(\Delta_{t}-m_{t}) (18)

Taking all these into account, we formally present our methods in Algorithm 2 and Algorithm 3.

5 Convergence Analysis

We give the theoretical analysis of PreFed and PreFedOpt in this section. In the standard federated learning Equation 1, we consider more realistic case that the function Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} (and therefore F𝐹F) may be non-convex. For each i𝑖i and w𝑤w, we assume gi​(w)subscript𝑔𝑖𝑤g_{i}(w) is an unbiased stochastic gradient estimation of the client true gradient ∇Fi​(x)∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝑥\nabla F_{i}(x). In addition, we make the following assumptions.

Assumption 1.

(Bounded gradient). The function Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} has bounded gradients, i.e., for any i∈[m],x∈Rdformulae-sequence𝑖delimited-[]𝑚𝑥superscript𝑅𝑑i\in[m],x\in R^{d} we have

‖∇Fi​(x)‖j≤G​ for all ​j∈[d]subscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝑥𝑗𝐺 for all 𝑗delimited-[]𝑑||\nabla F_{i}(x)||_{j}\leq G\text{\quad for all\quad}j\in[d]
Assumption 2.

(L-Lipschitz smooth). The function Fi​(⋅)subscript𝐹𝑖⋅F_{i}(\cdot) is L-Lipschitz smooth for all i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚i\in[m], i.e.

‖∇Fi​(x)−∇Fi​(y)‖≤L​‖x−y‖​ for all ​x,y∈Rdformulae-sequencenorm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝑥∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝑦𝐿norm𝑥𝑦 for all 𝑥𝑦superscript𝑅𝑑||\nabla F_{i}(x)-\nabla F_{i}(y)||\leq L||x-y||\text{\quad for all\quad}x,y\in R^{d}
Assumption 3.

(Bounded variance). The function Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} has σl​o​c​a​l2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑎𝑙2\sigma_{local}^{2}-bounded local variance i.e., 𝔼​‖gi,j−[∇Fi​(wi)]j‖=(σl​o​c​a​l)j2𝔼normsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑗subscriptdelimited-[]∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝑤𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜎𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑎𝑙𝑗2\mathbb{E}||g_{i,j}-[\nabla F_{i}(w_{i})]_{j}||=(\sigma_{local})_{j}^{2} for all wi∈Rd,j∈[d]formulae-sequencesubscript𝑤𝑖superscript𝑅𝑑𝑗delimited-[]𝑑w_{i}\in R^{d},j\in[d] and i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚i\in[m]. We also assume Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} has σg​l​o​b​a​l2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑔𝑙𝑜𝑏𝑎𝑙2\sigma_{global}^{2}-bounded global variance i.e., 𝔼​‖[∇Fi​(wi)]j−[∇F​(w)]j‖=(σg​l​o​b​a​l)j2𝔼normsubscriptdelimited-[]∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝑤𝑖𝑗subscriptdelimited-[]∇𝐹𝑤𝑗superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜎𝑔𝑙𝑜𝑏𝑎𝑙𝑗2\mathbb{E}||[\nabla F_{i}(w_{i})]_{j}-[\nabla F(w)]_{j}||=(\sigma_{global})_{j}^{2} for all wi∈Rd,j∈[d]formulae-sequencesubscript𝑤𝑖superscript𝑅𝑑𝑗delimited-[]𝑑w_{i}\in R^{d},j\in[d] and i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚i\in[m].

Assumptions 1 and 2 are widely used in nonconvex optimization literature [Reddi et al., 2018, Ward et al., 2018, Li et al., 2019]. Assumption 3 also has been used throughout various works on federated optimizations. We adopt Assumption 3 from [Reddi et al., 2020]. Assumption 3 bounds the variance among the client objective functions and the variance between the client objective function and the overall objective function. In addition, with a slight abuse of notation, we use σl2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑙2\sigma_{l}^{2} and σg2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑔2\sigma_{g}^{2} to denote ∑j=1d(σl​o​c​a​l)i,j2superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑑superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜎𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑗2\sum_{j=1}^{d}(\sigma_{local})_{i,j}^{2} and ∑j=1d(σg​l​o​b​a​l)i,j2superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑑superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜎𝑔𝑙𝑜𝑏𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑗2\sum_{j=1}^{d}(\sigma_{global})_{i,j}^{2} respectively.

We first present a lemma that bounds the divergence of the client model wi,ktsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘𝑡w_{i,k}^{t} to the overall model wtsubscript𝑤𝑡w_{t} among all workers, which is essential in our theory.

Lemma 1.

(Bounded Model Divergence) Let Assumptions 1, 2 and 3 hold, and any step size ηl≤15​K​Lsubscript𝜂𝑙15𝐾𝐿\eta_{l}\leq\frac{1}{\sqrt{5}KL}, we can bound the divergence of the client model wi,ktsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘𝑡w_{i,k}^{t} to the overall model wtsubscript𝑤𝑡w_{t} among all workers for any k∈{1,⋯​K−1}𝑘1⋯𝐾1k\in\{1,\cdots K-1\} as

CASE I: PreFed (Algorithm 2)

5K​L2​τ2​∑j=1d[(σlocal)j2+5​K​(σglobal)j2]+25L2​τ2​𝔼​‖∇F​(wt)‖25𝐾superscript𝐿2superscript𝜏2superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑑delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜎local𝑗25𝐾superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜎global𝑗225superscript𝐿2superscript𝜏2𝔼superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑡2\begin{split}\frac{5}{KL^{2}\tau^{2}}\sum_{j=1}^{d}[(\sigma_{\text{local}})_{j}^{2}+5K(\sigma_{\text{global}})_{j}^{2}]+\frac{25}{L^{2}\tau^{2}}\mathbb{E}||\nabla F(w_{t})||^{2}\end{split}

CASE II: PreFedOpt (Algorithm 3)

5L2​K​∑j=1d[(σlocal)j2+5​K​(σglobal)j2]+25L2​𝔼​‖∇F​(wt)‖2​`5superscript𝐿2𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑑delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜎local𝑗25𝐾superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜎global𝑗225superscript𝐿2𝔼superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑡2`\begin{split}\frac{5}{L^{2}K}\sum_{j=1}^{d}[(\sigma_{\text{local}})_{j}^{2}+5K(\sigma_{\text{global}})_{j}^{2}]+\frac{25}{L^{2}}\mathbb{E}||\nabla F(w_{t})||^{2}`\end{split}

The proof is deferred to appendix B. The above lemma shows that the divergence of client and overall model is mainly controlled by σlocalsubscript𝜎local\sigma_{\text{local}} and σglobalsubscript𝜎global\sigma_{\text{global}}. Compared to PreFedOpt, PreFed uses local adaptivity for client model update, and the model divergence is scaled to 1τ21superscript𝜏2\frac{1}{\tau^{2}}. Next, we provide the convergence analysis of PreFed.

Theorem 1.

(Convergence of PreFed) Let assume Assumptions 1, 2 and 3 hold, and let L,G,d,σlocal,σglobal𝐿𝐺𝑑subscript𝜎localsubscript𝜎globalL,G,d,\sigma_{\text{local}},\sigma_{\text{global}} be as defined therein. Let σ2=∑j=1d[(σlocal)j2+(5​K+32​m)​(σglobal)j2]superscript𝜎2superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑑delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜎local𝑗25𝐾32𝑚superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜎global𝑗2\sigma^{2}=\sum_{j=1}^{d}[(\sigma_{\text{local}})_{j}^{2}+(5K+\frac{3}{2m})(\sigma_{\text{global}})_{j}^{2}]. Assume the client models perform T𝑇T global synchronizations for every K𝐾K local updates. For any step size η𝜂\eta, then the Algorithm 2 for PreFed satisfy

min0≤t≤T−1⁡𝔼​‖∇F​(xt)‖2≤𝒪​(1T​[C1+G2​(L​η+375)​m])subscript0𝑡𝑇1𝔼superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝑥𝑡2𝒪1𝑇delimited-[]subscript𝐶1superscript𝐺2𝐿𝜂375𝑚\begin{split}&\min_{0\leq t\leq T-1}\mathbb{E}||\nabla F(x_{t})||^{2}\\ &\leq\mathcal{O}\bigg{(}\frac{1}{T}\Big{[}C_{1}+G^{2}\big{(}\frac{L\eta+3}{75}\big{)}m\Big{]}\bigg{)}\end{split} (19)

where

C1=2​m75​η​(F​(w0)−F​(wT−1))+L5​K​σ2subscript𝐶12𝑚75𝜂𝐹subscript𝑤0𝐹subscript𝑤𝑇1𝐿5𝐾superscript𝜎2C_{1}=\frac{2m}{75\eta}(F(w_{0})-F(w_{T-1}))+\frac{L}{5K}\sigma^{2} (20)

To obtain an explicit dependence on T𝑇T and K𝐾K, we simplify the above result for a specific choice of step size η𝜂\eta.

Corollary 1.

Suppose local step size ηlsubscript𝜂𝑙\eta_{l} in Lemma 1 is satisfied. Suppose η𝜂\eta satisfies η=Θ​(2​m/75​K)𝜂Θ2𝑚75𝐾\eta=\Theta(2\sqrt{m}/75\sqrt{K}). The for sufficiently large T𝑇T, the Algorithm 2 for for PreFed satisfy

min0≤t≤T−1⁡𝔼​‖∇F​(xt)‖2=𝒪​(F​(w0)−F​(wT−1)T​K​m+L​σ25​T​K+m​G225​T+2​L​m3/2​G2752​K​T)subscript0𝑡𝑇1𝔼superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝑥𝑡2𝒪𝐹subscript𝑤0𝐹subscript𝑤𝑇1𝑇𝐾𝑚𝐿superscript𝜎25𝑇𝐾𝑚superscript𝐺225𝑇2𝐿superscript𝑚32superscript𝐺2superscript752𝐾𝑇\begin{split}&\min_{0\leq t\leq T-1}\mathbb{E}||\nabla F(x_{t})||^{2}\\ &=\mathcal{O}\bigg{(}\frac{F(w_{0})-F(w_{T-1})}{T\sqrt{Km}}+\frac{L\sigma^{2}}{5TK}+\frac{mG^{2}}{25T}+\frac{2Lm^{3/2}G^{2}}{75^{2}\sqrt{K}T}\bigg{)}\end{split} (21)

The convergence analysis for PreFedOpt is different from PreFed because we only perform server-side adaptivity. We follow [Reddi et al., 2020] work with the general non-convex setting of our interest and provide PreFedOpt convergence.

Theorem 2.

(Convergence of PreFedOpt) Let assume Assumptions 1, 2 and 3 hold, and let L,G,d,σlocal,σglobal𝐿𝐺𝑑subscript𝜎localsubscript𝜎globalL,G,d,\sigma_{\text{local}},\sigma_{\text{global}} be as defined therein. Corollary 2.

6 Experiments

In this section, we present empirical evaluations of PreFed and PreFedOpt on different FL settings. We compare the performances of our methods to state-of-the-art approaches such as AdaAlter [Xie et al., 2019] and FedAdam [Reddi et al., 2020]. We highlight the benefits of introducing both client-side and server-side preconditioning to federated optimization.

Datasets and models. We use two popular image classification datasets: CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 [Krizhevsky, 2009]. The models we use for training are ResNet18 and ResNet34 [He et al., 2016], respectively. We train models under two settings: i.i.d. and non-i.i.d. Clients are sampled uniformly at random, without replacement in a given round, but with replacement across rounds. We implement all algorithms in the latest Pytorch 1.9 and provide an open-source implementation of all optimizers and benchmark tasks.

Algorithms and hyperparameters We train all models in E=80𝐸80E=80 global epochs. For each global epoch, we perform the global model synchronization for every K=500𝐾500K=500 iterations. For FedAvg, we use SGD with momentum as a local optimizer with step size ηl=0.05subscript𝜂𝑙0.05\eta_{l}=0.05 and momentum β=0.9𝛽0.9\beta=0.9. For AdaAlter and FedAdam, we set ηl=0.001,β1=0.9,β2=0.99formulae-sequencesubscript𝜂𝑙0.001formulae-sequencesubscript𝛽10.9subscript𝛽20.99\eta_{l}=0.001,\beta_{1}=0.9,\beta_{2}=0.99, and τ=0.001𝜏0.001\tau=0.001 which are the same as standard Adam settings. For PreFed and PreFedOpt, we set β2=0.9subscript𝛽20.9\beta_{2}=0.9. The server-side step size a in FedAdam and PreFedOpt, we use ηg=0.05subscript𝜂𝑔0.05\eta_{g}=0.05. We decay the local step size by 0.1 for every 20 global epochs, and we decay server-side step size by 0.1 for every 40 global epochs.

6.1 Results

The two sub-figures on the left of Figure 1 show the CIFAR10 on ResNet18 with i.i.d. settings. Both proposed algorithms perform better and achieve 88% and 87% accuracy on the validation dataset, respectively. The two sub-figures (on the right-side) display interesting results of different methods on the non-i.i.d. dataset. Our proposed methods outperform AdaAlter and FedAdam, both methods achieving 78% accuracy. We notice that the standard FedAvg has a large variance during the training (see the light blue region). This is mainly due to the data heterogeneity. On the other hand, adaptive methods reduce the noise of stochastic gradients and are more stable.

Experiments on CIFAR100 (Figure 2) show our algorithms continuously improve the model performance. Training with non-i.i.d settings of CIFAR100 is challenging because of the client models’ variance. When the number of clients increases, each client contains only a small part of the dataset, the gradient methods such as SGD causing significant model divergence. We will leave more experiment results in Appendix B.

7 Conclusion

In this paper, we present the preconditioned federated algorithms, PreFed and PreFedOpt, to improve the learning efficiency for FL optimization. We theoretically analyze their convergence behavior. Our experiments show proposed algorithms achieve state-of-the-art performances.
